statements.name: PROC COUNTREG
statements.description: The COUNTREG (count regression) procedure analyzes regression models in which the dependent variable takes nonnegative integer or count values. The dependent variable is usually an event count, which refers to the number of times an event occurs.

arguments.name: ABSCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function difference convergence criterion.

arguments.name: ABSGCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. Termination requires the maximum absolute gradient element to be small.

arguments.name: ABSXCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires a small Euclidean distance between successive parameter vectors.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates. This option can also be specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates. This option can also be specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: COVEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of covariance matrix of the parameter estimates. The quasi-maximum likelihood estimates are computed with COVEST=QML. The default is COVEST=HESSIAN.

arguments.name: OP
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product matrix.

arguments.name: HESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: QML
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product and Hessian matrices.

arguments.name: COVOUT
arguments.description: Writes the covariance matrix for the parameter estimates to the OUTEST= data set. This option is valid only if the OUTEST= option is specified.

arguments.name: DAMPSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies that the initial step-size value a⁰ for each line search (used by the QUANEW, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step-size value used in the former iteration.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set. If the DATA= option is not specified, PROC COUNTREG uses the most recently created SAS data set.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies a second function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: GROUPID=
arguments.description: Specifies an identification variable when a panel data model is estimated. The identification variable is used as a cross-sectional ID variable.

arguments.name: HESCAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian or crossproduct Jacobian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, LEVMAR, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.
Specifies that no scaling is done.
Specifies the Moré (1978) scaling update
Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

arguments.name: INHESSIAN=
arguments.description: Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

arguments.name: INSTEP=
arguments.description: Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

arguments.name: LINESEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.

Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

arguments.name: LSPRECISION=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the first n iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the iterative minimization method to use. The default is METHOD=NRA.
arguments.help: METHOD=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NRA | NRRIDG | QN | TR | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Specifies the conjugate-gradient method.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Specifies the double-dogleg method.

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Specifies the Nelder-Mead simplex method.

arguments.name: NRA
arguments.description: Specifies the Newton-Raphson method.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Specifies the Newton-Raphson ridge method.

arguments.name: QN
arguments.description: Specifies the quasi-Newton method.

arguments.name: TR
arguments.description: Specifies the trust region method.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no optimization be performed beyond using the ordinary least squares.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0.

arguments.name: NONORMALIZE
arguments.description: Does not row-normalize the spatial weights matrix that is specified in the WMAT= option. By default, the spatial weights matrix is required to be row-normalized; that is, the spatial weights matrix has unit row sum.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: OUTEST=
arguments.description: Writes the parameter estimates to an output data set.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: [Displays all optional output for optimization.

arguments.name: PHISTORY
arguments.description: Displays the optimization history. The PHISTORY option is set automatically if the PALL or PRINT option is set.

arguments.name: PHISTPARMS
arguments.description: Display parameter estimates in each iteration.

arguments.name: PINIT
arguments.description: Displays the initial values and derivatives (if available).

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Requests that the COUNTREG procedure produce statistical graphics via the Output Delivery System, provided that ODS GRAPHICS has been enabled.
arguments.help: PLOTS=ALL | AUTOCORR | BAYESDIAG | BAYESSUM | DENSITY | DISPERSION | PREDPROB | PREDPROFILE | PROFILELIKE | TRACE | ZEROPROFILE | NONE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that all plots appropriate for the particular analysis be produced.

arguments.name: AUTOCORR
arguments.description: Syntax: AUTOCORR<(LAGS=n)> Displays the autocorrelation function plots of the parameters. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.

arguments.name: BAYESDIAG
arguments.description: Displays the TRACE, AUTOCORR, and DENSITY plots. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.

arguments.name: BAYESSUM
arguments.description: displays the posterior distribution, prior distribution, and maximum likelihood estimates. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.

arguments.name: DENSITY
arguments.description: Syntax: DENSITY<(FRINGE)> Displays the kernel density plots of the parameters. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.

arguments.name: DISPERSION
arguments.description: Produces the overdispersion diagnostic plot.

arguments.name: PREDPROB
arguments.description: Produces the overall predictive probabilities of the specified count levels. You must also specify COUNTS in global-plot-options.

arguments.name: PREDPROFILE
arguments.description: Produces the predictive probability profiles of specified count levels against model regressors.

arguments.name: PROFILELIKE
arguments.description: Produces the profile likelihood functions of the model parameters.

arguments.name: TRACE
arguments.description: Displays the trace plots of the parameters. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.

arguments.name: ZEROPROFILE
arguments.description: Droduces the probability profiles of zero-inflation process selection and zero count prediction against model regressors.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all plots.

arguments.name: PSHORT
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default output.

arguments.name: PSUMMARY
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default displayed output to a short form of iteration history and notes, warnings, and errors.

arguments.name: RESTART=
arguments.description: Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent search direction after at most i iterations, i > 0.

arguments.name: RESTORE=
arguments.description: Specifies the source item store for processing. An item-store-name consists of a one- or two-level name, as with SAS data sets. As with data sets, an item store is associated by default with the Work library, and any item stores that are created in this library are deleted when the SAS session concludes.

arguments.name: SOCKET=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.
arguments.help: UPDATE=BFGS | DBFGS | DDFP | DFP | PB | FR | PR | CD

arguments.name: BFGS
arguments.description: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DBFGS
arguments.description: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.

arguments.name: DDFP
arguments.description: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DFP
arguments.description: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: PB
arguments.description: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).

arguments.name: FR
arguments.description: Performs the Fletcher-Reeves update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: PR
arguments.description: Performs the Polak-Ribiere update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: CD
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

arguments.name: WMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set that contains spatial weights matrix. The spatial weights matrix is often known as the W matrix.

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: BAYES
statements.description: The BAYES statement controls the Metropolis sampling scheme that is used to obtain samples from the posterior distribution of the underlying model and data.

arguments.name: AGGREGATION=
arguments.description: Specifies how multiple posterior samples should be aggregated.

arguments.name: WEIGHTED
arguments.description: Implements a weighted resampling scheme for the aggregation of multiple posterior chains. You can use this option when the posterior distribution is characterized by several very distinct posterior modes.

arguments.name: NOWEIGHTED
arguments.description: Aggregates multiple posterior chains without any adjustment. You can use this option when the posterior distribution is characterized by one or few relatively close posterior modes.

arguments.name: AUTOMCMC=
arguments.description: Specifies an algorithm for the automated initialization of the MCMC sampling algorithm. You can specify the following automcmc-options:
arguments.help: AUTOMCMC=ACCURACY= | ATTEMPTS= | TARGETESS= | TARGETSTATS | MAXNMC= | RANDINIT | MULTIPLIER= | PROPORTION= | STATIONARITY= | ATTEMPTS= | TOL=

arguments.name: DIAGNOSTICS=
arguments.description: Controls which diagnostics are produced. All the following diagnostics are produced by using DIAGNOSTICS=ALL. If you do not want any of these diagnostics, specify DIAGNOSTICS=NONE. If you want some but not all of the diagnostics, or if you want to change certain settings of these diagnostics, specify a subset of the following keywords. You can specify the following values; by default, DIAGNOSTICS=NONE.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: All diagnostics are produced.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all the diagnostics.

arguments.name: (keyword-list)
arguments.description: The following keywords are available: AUTOCORR <(autocorr-options)> -- computes default autocorrelations at lags 1, 5, 10, and 50 for each variable. You can choose other lags by using the following autocorrelation-option: LAGS=(numeric-list) AUTOMCMCSUM -- produces a summary table for the AUTOMCMC (automatic MCMC) sampling tool is used. ESS -- computes the effective sample sizes (Kass et al. (1998)) of the posterior samples of each parameter. GEWEKE <(FRAC1=value FRAC2=value)> computes the Geweke spectral density diagnostics, where FRAC1 and FRAC2 specify the beginning FRAC1 and end FRAC2 proportion of the Markov chain, respectively. HEIDELBERGER <(SALPHA=value value EPS=value)> computes the Heidelberger and Welch diagnostic (which consists of a stationarity test and a halfwidth test) for each variable. SALPHA= -- specifies the α level (0 < a < 1) for the stationarity test. By default, SALPHA=0.05 HALPHA= -- specifies the α level (0 < a < 1) for the halfwidth test. By default, HALPHA=0.05. EPS= -- specifies a small positive number ε such that if the halfwidth is less than ε times the sample mean of the retaining iterates, the halfwidth test is passed. MCSE | MCERROR -- computes the Monte Carlo standard error for each parameter. RAFTERY <(QUANTILE=value ACCURACY=value PROB=value EPS=value QUANTILE=value)> computes the Raftery and Lewis diagnostics.

arguments.name: MARGINLIKE=
arguments.description: Requests evaluation of the logarithm of the marginal likelihood. Two estimates are produced: the cross-entropy estimate and the harmonic mean. The cross-entropy estimate is based on an importance sampling algorithm for which you can specify the number of importance samples in the NSIM= suboption. The default is 10,000.

arguments.name: MAXTUNE=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of tuning phases. By default, MAXTUNE=24.

arguments.name: MINTUNE=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of tuning phases. By default, MINTUNE=2.

arguments.name: NBI=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of burn-in iterations before the chains are saved. By default, NBI=1000.

arguments.name: NMC=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of iterations after the burn-in for Metropolis sampling scheme. By default, NMC=1000.

arguments.name: NTRDS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of threads to be used. The number of threads cannot exceed the number of computer cores available. Each core samples the number of iterations that is specified by the NMC= option. By default, NTRDS=1.

arguments.name: NTU=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of samples for each tuning phase for Metropolis sampling schemes. By default, NTU=500.

arguments.name: OUTPOST=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set to contain the posterior samples. Alternatively, you can create the output data set by specifying an ODS OUTPUT statement as follows:

arguments.name: PROPCOV=
arguments.description: Specifies the method to use in constructing the initial covariance matrix for the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm.
arguments.help: PROPCOV=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NEWRAP | NNSIMP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-gradient optimization.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization that combines a line-search algorithm with ridging.

arguments.name: NNSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization with ridging.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Performs a quasi-Newton optimization.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a trust-region optimization.

arguments.name: SAMPLING=
arguments.description: Specifies how to sample from the posterior distribution.

arguments.name: MODELMETROPOLIS
arguments.description: Implements a Metropolis sampling scheme on multiple blocks: one block for each model (all the parameters of the model) plus a block for all the correlation parameters across the models.

arguments.name: MULTIMETROPOLIS
arguments.description: implements a Metropolis sampling scheme on a single block that contains all the parameters of the model. SAMPLING=MULTIMETROPOLIS is the default option.

arguments.name: UNIMETROPOLIS
arguments.description: Implements a Metropolis sampling scheme on multiple blocks, one for each parameter of the model.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies an integer seed in the range 1 to 2^31 - 1 for the random number generator in the simulation. Specifying a seed enables you to reproduce identical Markov chains for the same specification. If you do not specify the SEED= option, or if you specify SEED=0, a random seed is derived from the time of day, which is read from the computer’s clock.

arguments.name: SIMTIME
arguments.description: Prints the time required for the MCMC sampling.

arguments.name: STATISTICS=
arguments.description: Controls the number of posterior statistics that are produced.
arguments.help: STATISTICS=CORR | COV | INTERVAL | PRIOR | SUMMARY | NONE

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Produces the posterior correlation matrix.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Produces the posterior covariance matrix.

arguments.name: INTERVAL
arguments.description: Produces equal-tail credible intervals and HPD intervals.

arguments.name: PRIOR
arguments.description: Produces a summary table of the prior distributions that are used in the Bayesian analysis.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Produces the means, standard deviations, and percentile points (25th, 50th, and 75th) of the posterior samples.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses printing of all summary statistics.

arguments.name: THIN=
arguments.description: Controls the thinning of the Markov chain.

statements.name: BOUNDS
statements.description: The BOUNDS statement imposes simple boundary constraints on the parameter estimates. BOUNDS statement constraints refer to the parameters estimated by the COUNTREG procedure. You can specify any number of BOUNDS statements.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC COUNTREG to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the input data set should be sorted in order of the BY variables.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables that are used to group (classify) data in the analysis. Classification variables can be either character or numeric.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid values for the CLASS variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of classification variables.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Sorts levels by the order of appearance in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Sorts levels by external formatted values, except for numeric variables that have no explicit format.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Sorts levels by descending frequency count; levels that have more observations come earlier in the order. .

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Sorts levels by unformatted value. Ths sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: PARAM=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: Uses effect coding to create design matrix columns from the CLASS variables.

arguments.name: GLM
arguments.description: Uses less-than-full-rank reference cell coding to create design matrix columns from the CLASS variables.

arguments.name: REFERENCE
arguments.description: Uses reference cell coding to create design matrix columns from the CLASS variables.

arguments.name: REF=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference level for PARAM=EFFECT, or PARAM=REFERENCE, and their orthogonalizations.

arguments.name: ‘level’
arguments.description: For an individual (but not a global) variable REF= option, you can specify the level of the variable to use as the reference level. Replace 'level' with an actual value, enclosed in quotes.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first-ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last-ordered level as reference.

statements.name: DISPMODEL
statements.description: The DISPMODEL statement specifies the dispersion-related-regressors that are used to model dispersion. This statement is ignored unless you specify DIST=COMPOISSON in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: SELECT=
arguments.description: Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement specifies a variable whose values represent the frequency of occurrence of each observation. PROC COUNTREG treats each observation as if it appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation. If the frequency value is not an integer, it is truncated to an integer; if it is less than 1 or missing, the observation is not used in the model fitting. When the FREQ statement is not specified, each observation is assigned a frequency of 1. If you specify more than one FREQ statement, then the first statement is used.

statements.name: INIT
statements.description: The INIT statement sets initial values for parameters in the optimization. Each initvalue is written as a parameter or parameter list, followed by an optional equal sign (=), followed by a number: parameter <=> number For continuous regressors, the names of the parameters are the same as the corresponding variables. For a regressor that is a CLASS variable, the parameter name combines the corresponding CLASS variable name with the variable level. For interaction and nested regressors, the parameter names combine the names of each regressor. The names of the parameters can be seen in the OUTEST= data set. By default, initial values are determined by OLS regression. Initial values can be displayed with the ITPRINT option in the PROC statement.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the dependent variable and independent regressor variables for the regression model. If you specify no regressors, PROC COUNTREG fits a model that contains only an intercept. The dependent count variable should take on only nonnegative integer values in the input data set. PROC COUNTREG rounds any positive noninteger count values to the nearest integer. PROC COUNTREG ignores any observations with a negative count. Only one MODEL statement can be specified.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates. It can also be specified in the PROC COUNTREG statement.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates. It can also be specified in the PROC COUNTREG statement.

arguments.name: DIST=
arguments.description: Specifies a type of model to be analyzed. If you specify this option in both the MODEL statement and the PROC COUNTREG statement, then only the value in the MODEL statement is used.
arguments.help: DIST=COMPOISSON | NEGBIN(P=1) | NEGBIN(P=2) | POISSON | ZICOMPOISSON | ZINEGBIN | ZIPOISSON

arguments.name: COMPOISSON
arguments.description: Specifies a Conway-Maxwell-Poisson regression model.

arguments.name: NEGBIN
arguments.description: Specifies a negative binomial regression model that uses a linear variance function

arguments.name: NEGBIN
arguments.description: Specifies a negative binomial regression model that users a quadratic variance function

arguments.name: POISSON
arguments.description: Specifies a Poisson regression model.

arguments.name: ZICOMPOISSON
arguments.description: Specifies a zero-inflated Conway-Maxwell-Poisson regression.

arguments.name: ZINEGBIN
arguments.description: Specifies a zero-inflated negative binomial regression.

arguments.name: ZIPOISSON
arguments.description: Specifies a zero-inflated Poisson regression.

arguments.name: ERRORCOMP=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of conditional panel model to be analyzed.

arguments.name: FIXED
arguments.description: Specifies a fixed-effect error component regression model.

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Specifies a random-effect error component regression model.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Prints the objective function and parameter estimates at each iteration. The objective function is the negative log-likelihood function. It can also be specified in the PROC COUNTREG statement.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept parameter.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as an offset variable. The offset variable appears as a covariate in the model with its parameter restricted to 1.

arguments.name: PARAMETER=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson model.

arguments.name: MU
arguments.description: Reparameterizes lambda as documented by Guikema and Coffelt (2008).

arguments.name: LAMBDA
arguments.description: Estimates the original Conway-Maxwell-Poisson model (Shmueli et al. 2005).

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Requests all printing options. It can also be specified in the PROC COUNTREG statement.

arguments.name: SELECT=
arguments.description: Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.
arguments.help: SELECT=DIRECTION= | CRITER=LSTOP= | MAXSTEPS= | NOSPLITEFFECTS | RETAIN | RETAINEFFECT | GVC | GVC1 | GVCLENGTH= | LAMBDA= | LLASTEPS=

statements.name: NLOPTIONS
statements.description: Several SAS/ETS procedures (COUNTREG, ENTROPY, MDC, QLIM, UCM, and VARMAX) use the nonlinear optimization (NLO) subsystem to perform nonlinear optimization.

arguments.name: ABSCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value of r is the negative square root of the largest double-precision value, which serves only as a protection against overflows.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value is r=0. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSGCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-5. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSXCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. The default is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: DAMPSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies that the initial step length value a⁰ for each line search (used by the QUANEW, HYQUAN, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step length value used in the former iteration. If the DAMPSTEP option is specified but r is not specified, the default is r=2. The DAMPSTEP=r option can prevent the line-search algorithm from repeatedly stepping into regions where some objective functions are difficult to compute or where they could lead to floating point overflows during the computation of objective functions and their derivatives. The DAMPSTEP=r option can save time-costly function calls during the line searches of objective functions that result in very small steps.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies another function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-8. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: HESCAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.
Specifies that no scaling is done.
Specifies the Moré (1978) scaling update
Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

arguments.name: INHESSIAN=
arguments.description: Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

arguments.name: INSTEP=
arguments.description: Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

arguments.name: LINESEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.

Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

arguments.name: LSPRECISION=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are: o For TECH= TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: i=50 o For TECH= QUANEW, DBLDOG: i=200 o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400 o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=1000 These default values are also valid when i is specified as a missing value.

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the first n iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer. Note that the time specified by the MAXTIME= option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the actual running time can be much longer than that specified by the MAXTIME= option. The actual running time includes the rest of the time needed to finish the iteration and the time needed to generate the output of the results.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0. If you request more iterations than are actually needed for convergence to a stationary point, the optimization algorithms can behave strangely. For example, the effect of rounding errors can prevent the algorithm from continuing for the required number of iterations.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the output.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: [Displays all optional output for optimization.

arguments.name: PHISTORY
arguments.description: Displays the optimization history.

arguments.name: PHISTPARMS
arguments.description: Display parameter estimates in each iteration.

arguments.name: PINIT
arguments.description: Displays the initial values and derivatives (if available).

arguments.name: PSHORT
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default output.

arguments.name: PSUMMARY
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default displayed output to a short form of iteration history and notes, warnings, and errors.

arguments.name: RESTART=
arguments.description: Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent search direction after, at most, i iterations, i > 0.

arguments.name: SOCKET=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.
arguments.help: UPDATE=BFGS | DBFGS | DDFP | DFP | PB | FR | PR | CD

arguments.name: BFGS
arguments.description: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DBFGS
arguments.description: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.

arguments.name: DDFP
arguments.description: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DFP
arguments.description: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: PB
arguments.description: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).

arguments.name: FR
arguments.description: Performs the Fletcher-Reeves update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: PR
arguments.description: Performs the Polak-Ribiere update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: CD
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. For all techniques except NMSIMP, termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations. The default value is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set containing all the variables in the input data set and, optionally, the estimates of x'β, the expected value of the response variable, and the probability that the response variable will take on the current value.

arguments.name: DISPERSION=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the value of dispersion for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: GDELTA=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains estimates of g’δ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of λ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the integral part of μ (mode) for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: MU=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of μ or the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: NU=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of ν for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set.

arguments.name: PRED=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the predicted value of the response variable.

arguments.name: PROB=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the probability of the response variable taking the current value, Pr(Y=y).

arguments.name: PROBCOUNT
arguments.description: Outputs the probability that the response variable will take particular values.

arguments.name: PROBZERO=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the value of ϕ, the probability of the response variable taking on the value of zero as a result of the zero-generating process.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of variance.

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing estimates of x'β.

arguments.name: ZGAMMA=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing estimates of z'ϒ.

statements.name: PERFORMANCE
statements.description: The PERFORMANCE statement controls the number of threads that are used in the optimization phase.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: Specifies that a timing table be included in the output.

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: Specifies that no threads should be used during optimization of the model.

arguments.name: NTHREADS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of threads to be used during optimization of the model.

statements.name: PRIOR
statements.description: The PRIOR statement is used to specify the prior distribution of the model parameters. You must specify a single parameter or a list of parameters, a tilde ~, and then a distribution with its parameters. Multiple PRIOR statements are allowed.
statements.help: PRIOR <BETA(SHAPE1=a, SHAPE2=b, MIN=m, MAX=M)> <GAMMA(SHAPE=a, SCALE=b)> <IGAMMA(SHAPE=a, SCALE=b)> ...

arguments.name: BETA
arguments.description: Specifies a beta distribution that has the parameters SHAPE1 and SHAPE2 and is defined between MIN and MAX.

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Specifies a gamma distribution that has the parameters SHAPE and SCALE.

arguments.name: IGAMMA
arguments.description: Specifies an inverse gamma distribution that has the parameters SHAPE and SCALE.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Specifies a normal distribution that has the parameters MEAN and VAR.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: Specifies a noncentral t distribution that has DF degrees of freedom and a location parameter equal to LOCATION.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: Specifies a uniform distribution that is defined between MIN and MAX.

statements.name: RESTRICT
statements.description: The RESTRICT statement imposes linear restrictions on the parameter estimates. You can specify any number of RESTRICT statements. Each restriction is written either as a single linear equation or as a comma-separated list of two or more linear equations. A restriction equation consists of an expression, followed by an equality operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, <=, >=), followed by a second expression: expression operator expression The operator can be =, <, >, <=, or >=.

statements.name: SCORE
statements.description: The SCORE statement enables you to compute predicted values and other statistics for a SAS data set.

arguments.name: DISPERSION=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the value of dispersion for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: GDELTA=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains estimates of g’δ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of λ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the integral part of μ (mode) for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: MU=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of μ or the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: NU=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of ν for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set.

arguments.name: PRED=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the predicted value of the response variable.

arguments.name: PROB=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the probability of the response variable taking the current value, Pr(Y=y).

arguments.name: PROBCOUNT
arguments.description: Outputs the probability that the response variable will take particular values.

arguments.name: PROBZERO=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the value of ϕ, the probability of the response variable taking on the value of zero as a result of the zero-generating process.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains the estimate of variance.

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing estimates of x'β.

arguments.name: ZGAMMA=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing estimates of z'ϒ.

statements.name: SHOW
statements.description: The SHOW statement displays the contents of the item store. You can use the SHOW statement to verify the contents of the item store before proceeding with the analysis.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Displays all applicable contents

arguments.name: CLASSLEVELS
arguments.description: Displays the "Class Level Information" table. This table is produced by the COUNTREG procedure by default if the model contains effects that depend on classification variables.

arguments.name: CORRELATION
arguments.description: Produces the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVARIANCE
arguments.description: shows all open SAS data sets.

arguments.name: EFFECTS
arguments.description: Displays information about the effects in the model.

arguments.name: FILES
arguments.description: Produces the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: FITSTATS
arguments.description: Displays the fit statistics from the item store.

arguments.name: PARAMETERS
arguments.description: Displays the parameter estimates table from the item store.

arguments.name: PROGRAM
arguments.description: Displays the SAS program that generates the item store, provided that this was stored at store generation time. The program does not include comments, titles, or some other global statements.

statements.name: SPATIALDISPEFFECTS
statements.description: The SPATIALDISPEFFECTS statement adds the spatially weighted dispersion-spatial-effect-regressors to regressors that are specified in the DISPMODEL statement.

arguments.name: SELECT=
arguments.description: Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

statements.name: SPATIALEFFECTS
statements.description: The SPATIALEFFECTS statement adds the spatially weighted model-spatial-effect-regressors to regressors that are specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: SELECT=
arguments.description: Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

statements.name: SPATIALID
statements.description: For a spatial lag of X model, the SPATIALID statement specifies a variable that identifies a spatial unit for each observation in the two data sets that are provided by the DATA= and WMAT= options in the PROC COUNTREG statement.

statements.name: SPATIALZEROEFFECTS
statements.description: The SPATIALZEROEFFECTS statement adds the spatially weighted zero-inflation-spatial-effect-regressors to regressors that are specified in the ZEROMODEL statement.

arguments.name: SELECT=
arguments.description: Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

statements.name: STORE
statements.description: The STORE statement saves the contents of the analysis to an item store in a binary format that cannot be modified. You can restore the stored information by specifying the RESTORE= option in the PROC COUNTREG statement and use it in postprocessing analysis.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the item store name where the contents of the analysis are saved.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests of linear hypotheses about the regression parameters that are specified in the preceding MODEL statement.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.

arguments.name: LM
arguments.description: Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.

arguments.name: LR
arguments.description: Requests the likelihood ratio test.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests the Wald test.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies a variable to supply weighting values to use for each observation in estimating parameters. The log likelihood for each observation is multiplied by the corresponding weight variable value. If the weight of an observation is nonpositive, that observation is not used in the estimation.

arguments.name: NONORMALIZE
arguments.description: Does not normalize the weights. By default, the weights are normalized so that they add up to the actual sample size.

statements.name: ZEROMODEL
statements.description: The ZEROMODEL statement is required if either ZIP or ZINB is specified in the DIST= option in the MODEL statement. If ZIP or ZINB is specified, then the ZEROMODEL statement must follow immediately after the MODEL statement. The dependent variable in the ZEROMODEL statement must be the same as the dependent variable in the MODEL statement. The zero-inflated (ZI) regressors appear in the equation that determines the probability of a zero count.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the distribution function used to compute probability of zeros.

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Specifies logistic distribution.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Specifies standard normal distribution.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as a zero-inflated (ZI) offset variable.
